aws::graph::propositions: # Administrative Information for NTSB Investigation 87473
Zoe Keliher is the Investigator In Charge (IIC) of the investigation.
Timothy Markle is an additional participating person in the investigation.
Timothy Markle represents the Federal Aviation Administration.
Timothy Markle is based in Helena, Montana.
The original publish date of the accident report is September 12, 2013.
The investigation is classified as a Class investigation.
The accident report documents the factual circumstances of the accident as described to the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB).
The investigation docket is available at https://data.ntsb.gov/Docket?ProjectID=87473.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is an independent federal agency.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is charged by Congress with investigating every civil aviation accident in the United States.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) investigates significant events in other modes of transportation.
Other modes of transportation include railroad, transit, highway, marine, pipeline, and commercial space.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) determines the probable causes of the accidents and events it investigates.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) issues safety recommendations aimed at preventing future occurrences.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) conducts transportation safety research studies.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) offers information and assistance to family members and survivors for each accident or event it investigates.

The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) serves as the appellate authority for enforcement actions involving aviation and mariner certificates issued by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) serves as the appellate authority for enforcement actions involving aviation and mariner certificates issued by the US Coast Guard.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) adjudicates appeals of civil penalty actions taken by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) does not assign fault or blame for an accident or incident.
NTSB regulation specifies that accident/incident investigations are fact-finding proceedings with no formal issues and no adverse parties.
NTSB investigations are not conducted for the purpose of determining the rights or liabilities of any person.
This specification is found in Title 49 Code of Federal Regulations section 831.4.
Assignment of fault or legal liability is not relevant to the National Transportation Safety Board's statutory mission.
The National Transportation Safety Board's statutory mission is to improve transportation safety by investigating accidents and incidents and issuing safety recommendations.
Statutory language prohibits the admission into evidence or use of any part of an NTSB report related to an accident in a civil action for damages.
This prohibition applies to matters mentioned in the report.
This prohibition is found in Title 49 United States Code section 1154(b).
A factual report that may be admissible under 49 United States Code section 1154(b) is available on the NTSB website.

text:
# Administrative Information

## Investigator In Charge (IIC):
Keliher, Zoe

## Additional Participating Persons:
Timothy Markle; Federal Aviation Administration; Helena, MT

## Original Publish Date:
September 12, 2013

## Last Revision Date:

## Investigation Class:
Class

## Note:
This accident report documents the factual circumstances of this accident as described to the NTSB.

## Investigation Docket:
[https://data.ntsb.gov/Docket?ProjectID=87473](https://data.ntsb.gov/Docket?ProjectID=87473)

The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is an independent federal agency charged by Congress with investigating every civil aviation accident in the United States and significant events in other modes of transportationrailroad, transit, highway, marine, pipeline, and commercial space. We determine the probable causes of the accidents and events we investigate, and issue safety recommendations aimed at preventing future occurrences. In addition, we conduct transportation safety research studies and offer information and other assistance to family members and survivors for each accident or event we investigate. We also serve as the appellate authority for enforcement actions involving aviation and mariner certificates issued by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and US Coast Guard, and we adjudicate appeals of civil penalty actions taken by the FAA.

The NTSB does not assign fault or blame for an accident or incident; rather, as specified by NTSB regulation, "accident/incident investigations are fact-finding proceedings with no formal issues and no adverse parties  and are not conducted for the purpose of determining the rights or liabilities of any person" (Title 49 Code of Federal Regulations section 831.4). Assignment of fault or legal liability is not relevant to the NTSB's statutory mission to improve transportation safety by investigating accidents and incidents and issuing safety recommendations. In addition, statutory language prohibits the admission into evidence or use of any part of an NTSB report related to an accident in a civil action for damages resulting from a matter mentioned in the report (Title 49 United States Code section 1154(b)). A factual report that may be admissible under 49 United States Code section 1154(b) is available [here](https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/aviation.aspx).
